title: Domaine des Etangs: Stay in billionaire's 11th-century storybook turreted French castle
text:
Domaine des Etangs: Stay in billionaire's 11th-century storybook turreted French castle Last updated 13:00, July 27 2015 
Chateau et la Chapelle. 
Romantic stays do not come more fairytale-like than this – the 850-hectare holiday home of oil billionaire, Didier Primat, one of France's richest men before his death in 2008, has just opened to the public as a resort. 
Domaine des Etangs​ is in Charente Limousine, a rural, sparsely populated region of France, three hours out of Paris, where few tourists venture despite pretty, quiet villages and bucolic scenery. 
Primat's daughter Garance​ has transformed the family retreat with the assistance of French landscape designer Camille Muller and highly sought-after Parisian architect Isabelle Stanislas​ to create a hotel that includes seven unique suites in the 11th-century storybook turreted castle, plus cottages spaced privately around the grounds making a total of 29 rooms. 
There's a 40-seat restaurant and thermal baths set among an ever-changing 850 hectares for cycling, horse riding, walking or even some gentle boating in the woodland lakes dotted throughout. 
Bike-riding at Domaine Massignac. 
Original features have been preserved and exposed as much as possible under the loving care of local craftsmen and contemporary touches have been cleverly melded with family antiques and important artworks. 
The restaurant is fuelled by local produce, a prolific kitchen garden and livestock from the property. There's an 18-hole golf course within 20 kilometres and an adventure park with flying foxes and treetop walks not too far away, should all that perfect peace get too much. 
Domaine des Etangs is a member of the Small Luxury Hotels of the World group of luxury boutique properties. From around $970 (low season) and up to around $2985 (high season) a night. See slh.com/DomaineDesEtangs .
